Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Natural Chromogenic Behaviors of Squid in Oceanic Waters
Award.AbstractNarration:
Complex color-changing (chromogenic) behaviors in squid provide camouflage by mimicking benthic features such as rocks, coral or algae, and also serve in intra-specific signaling. However, few studies have been carried out under natural lighting conditions in the field, or without the presence of human observers or noisy remotely operated vehicles. This project will extend field studies of natural chromogenic behaviors to the family Ommastrephidae as exemplified by Dosidicus gigas (Humboldt squid). To accomplish the research under natural lighting conditions, the project will develop an improved low-light Crittercam and an improved Driftcam that can operate effectively at greater depths. These improved video platforms will lead to new understanding of the generation and regulation of camouflage and communication in the open-ocean environment. Little is known of predatory behavior in midwater region occupied by Humboldt squid, which in the eastern Pacific Ocean is associated with a vast volume of water that is naturally hypoxic called the oxygen minimum zone (OMZ). This OMZ is currently expanding and moving toward the surface, largely due to climate change. Observations of predatory activity in the upper OMZ will increase our understanding of how pelagic ecosystems might change as climate change progresses, and how these changes could impact economically and ecologically important species like the Humboldt squid.

Chromogenic behavior in squid and other cephalopods is generated by muscular organs called chromatophores that are controlled by neural activity in the brain, and this direct, descending motor-control for chromatophores is unique to cephalopods. Pilot studies with the National Geographic Remote Imaging (NGRI) "Crittercam" video-package deployed on free-swimming Humboldt under natural lighting have revealed static patterning-type displays, like those seen in loliginid species, as well as a unique "flashing" behavior, with the entire body rapidly alternating between pale white and deep red. Flashing appeared to occur only during interactions with conspecifics, strongly suggesting a communication role. These data also revealed a more subtle wave-like "flickering" of chromatophores that may emulate fluctuations of light in the water column and provide dynamic countershading or crypsis. Neither type of behavior has been described in the scientific literature. The generation and control of the flashing and flickering chromatophore signals is therefore of great interest. This project will increase our knowledge of chromatophore signals through in situ video observations and anatomic analyses of Humboldt squid that include electrophysiology assessments, and immunohistochemical analyses of mantle tissue. An improved version of an autonomous low-light drift-camera package ("Driftcam") that can operate at midwater depths to observe natural behaviors of Humboldt squid that are too small to carry a Crittercam will be developed during the course of the project. Stanford graduate and undergraduate students will benefit from direct involvement in all of the research activities, and the researchers will also participate in wider public science dissemination efforts through regional K-12 programs, international educational outreach programs, and collaboration with major public media outlets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Color-changing (chromogenic) behavior in squid, cuttlefish, and octopus is generated by muscular organs called chromatophores that are controlled by nerve fibers emanating from the brain. These organs are composed of an elastic, pigment-containing sac attached to a radially oriented ring of muscle fibers. When excited by glutamate released by the motor nerve endings, muscle fibers open the sac to display a spot of pigment. Serotonin inhibits this activity. Neural activity in the brain thus underlies dynamic patterning of skin color that changes over space and time and serves in camouflage and communication. Descending “vertical” control of this sort is widely accepted, but a “horizontal” control pathway between chromatophores has also been proposed. Although coordinated waves of chromatophore activity are readily apparent in some squid after motor nerve inputs are surgically disrupted and allowed to degenerate, anatomical evidence for a horizontal control pathway and physiological information regarding transmission mechanisms are lacking. Studies of horizontal control in conjunction with natural chromogenic behaviors in the field are also lacking. This project addressed these shortcomings by taking advantage of certain squid that may display horizontal control to an unusually high degree through lab studies using physiological and immunohistochemical approaches and through field studies by developing a low-light imaging platform to facilitate minimally invasive observation of squid in the water column.

This project revealed spontaneous waves of chromatophore activity during “flickering” behavior in the oceanic Humboldt squid (Dosidicus gigas; family Ommstrephidae) studied with the National Geographic Crittercam (Rosen and Gilly, 2015), as well as in isolated skin preparations with nervous control blocked by tetrodotoxin (TTX) (Rosen and Gilly, Submitted to J. Experimental Biology). Such TTX-resistant waves are evident in coastal squid species, such as the California market squid (Doryteuthis opalescens) (family Loliginidae) only after denervation of chromatophores by cutting the motor nerves and allowing the nerve endings to degenerate. In all cases, waves are blocked by application of serotonin, an endogenous inhibitor that is normally associated with nerve endings. This work strongly suggests that similar horizontal control mechanisms exist in both families of squid, but that they are normally strongly inhibited by serotonin in loliginid species. Immunohistochemical indicated that the serotonergic innervation of chromatophores in Dosidicus was meager in comparison to Doryteuthis. These data also revealed a high frequency (~8%) of contacts between branching muscle fibers of different chromatophores in Dosidicus vs. < 1% in Doryteuthis. Connections between muscle fibers may thus provide a direct pathway for activity of one chromatophore to spread to another.

In collaboration with National Geographic Remote Imaging this project developed “Driftcam,” a semi-autonomous, low-light video-package that drifts at midwater depths to observe natural behavior of squid and their prey, particularly in association with acoustic scattering layers that can be tracked using sonar from a surface vessel. Vertical position of Driftcam is controlled by a novel buoyancy engine via an acoustic-modem link to the vessel. The system is deployable from a small vessel at a fraction of the cost of other methods. This approach will  lead to new understanding of camouflage and communication in the open-ocean environment inhabited by species like Dosidicus. Low-light video systems of relatively low-cost developed in the course of this project will advance research on other difficult-to-study aquatic species in marine and fresh-water environments.

This project provides a new view of chromatophore control in squid through an integrative approach that reaches from whole-animal behavior down to anatomy and function of nerve and muscle cells. It also extends our understanding of chromogenic behavior and chromatophore function to the oceanic ommastrephid squids, which as a group are understudied despite their great ecological and commercial value. In general terms, horizontal control is peripheral and distributed, with a potential for generating non-predictable, emergent phenomena, whereas vertical control is centralized and hierarchical (top-down). How such fundamentally different control systems work together is of interest to a broad sector of society, including engineering, economics, and politics.

Training was provided to Stanford graduate and undergraduate students. Collaborations with a technical college in Mexico were expanded to involve Mexican undergraduates and the local squid fishing community. Findings of the project were incorporated into an established outreach program (Squids4Kids) that supports K-12 education in the US and into a major cephalopod exhibition being developed by the Monterey Bay Aquarium. The PI co-directed a NEH Summer Institute (John Steinbeck: Social Critic and Ecologist) for twenty-five high-school teachers at Hopkins Marine Station that linked science and humanities and incorporated concepts of vertical vs. horizontal control, as well as ecological ideas of marine biologist Ed Ricketts,  into discussions of  Steinbeck’s fiction and non-fiction.
